snippet: Police officers and prosecutors give tips on civil asset forfeiture, the practice allowing the government, without ever filing a criminal charge, to seize property believed to have ties to crime, in seminars across the country.
abstract: Civil asset forfeiture allows government, without a conviction or even a criminal charge, to seize property that is itself possibly tied to criminal activity; practice has come under fire from civil rights activists and members of Congress, but forfeiture operations are being established or expanded across the nation despite opposition; continuing education seminars on process, aimed at local prosecutors and police, are flourishing.

byline.contributor: Clay Bolton contributed reporting from Georgia.

lead_paragraph: Police officers and prosecutors give tips on civil asset forfeiture, the practice allowing the government, without ever filing a criminal charge, to seize property believed to have ties to crime, in seminars across the country.
